author: Hannah Furness , Arts Correspondent
title: Don't let feminism kill off chivalry, Emilia Fox says
text: Chivalry must not be killed off by feminism, the actress Emilia Fox has said, as she argues equal rights do not mean gentlemen should no longer open doors for women. Fox, star of Silent Witness, said she "loves it" when "gentlemen are allowed to be gentlemen", opening doors or giving up their seat for her. The 41-year-old described herself as a "die-hard, old-fashioned romantic", adding she believes in equality but would not wish it to discourage men from their manners. In an interview with Good Housekeeping magazine, she said: "I believe in equality. But equally I love it when gentlemen are allowed to be gentlemen. "I don’t think we want to kill that off with the word feminism. "When a gentleman is kind to you and opens a door, or gives up his seat or says something nice, we must encourage that too. It’s lovely! "The age of chivalry should not die. The age of equality should exist with it." In an interview with Good Housekeeping magazine, Emilia Fox said: "I believe in equality. But equally I love it when gentlemen are allowed to be gentlemen Fox, a divorced mother-of-one who has recently worked as an ambassador for ActionAid in Ethiopia, said she would "love" to marry again, and has decorated her house to be "literally full of hearts and flowers". When asked about appearing onscreen, and body confidence, she said she is happy having a "darn good time" in her 40s, and sees "no point fighting" age. She told the magazine cosmetic surgery was "absolutely" down to individual choice, but had no plans to go under the knife herself. "I have many reasons not to have work done, and one is that I’m frightened of needles," she said. "Also facial expressions are so important in the world that I’m in. "But goodness knows what tomorrow will bring! I’m hoping one day they will invent something which will be so non-intrusive and will literally iron out all the wrinkles." The full interview appears in the August issue of Good Housekeeping, on sale from July 2nd and available in a digital edition. Follow @telegraphnews
